bibl.title: Two Loves I Have: Dioscorus, Apollo, Daphne, Hyacinth. Avec résumé en anglais.
bibl.note: P. Cairo Masp. II, 67188 verso (= M.-P.3 348.23; LDAB 6241), 11-16 = DIOSCORUS, Poem 41: an allegory of the doctus poeta positioned between literature (figured as Daphne, the laurel of poetic immortality) and philosophy (figured as Hyacinth whose death obeyed the laws of physics as expounded by Philoponus).
bibl.seg: MacCOULL Leslie S.B., Two Loves I Have: Dioscorus, Apollo, Daphne, Hyacinth. Avec résumé en anglais.

P. Cairo Masp. II, 67188 verso (= M.-P.3 348.23; LDAB 6241), 11-16 = DIOSCORUS, Poem 41: an allegory of the doctus poeta positioned between literature (figured as Daphne, the laurel of poetic immortality) and philosophy (figured as Hyacinth whose death obeyed the laws of physics as expounded by Philoponus).
